definition: An unconditional interest in land, for example, a lease to A for 99 years.
A full title to land guaranteed by HM Land Registry. It is the best class of title in registered land and can be either freehold or leasehold.
A summary of deeds, documents and events (e.g. deaths) which show a person’s title to unregistered land. It may be written in legal shorthand (that is lots of abbreviated words).

A doctrine which applies to all land with a water boundary whereby the title of the adjoining owner extends to that land as added to or detracted from by gradual and imperceptible additions or losses in the ordinary course of nature.

This was the official appointed by the Lord Chancellor under s.107 LRA 2002. The post of adjudicator is now defunct. Prior to 1 July 2013, the adjudicator had the power to determine the matters in dispute or to direct a party to commence court proceedings for the purpose of obtaining the court’s decision on the matter. The adjudicator was entirely independent of HM Land Registry. Land Registration division of the Property Chamber, First-tier Tribunal took over the Adjudicator to HM Land Registry role from 1 July 2013.
